 I 1. INTRODUCTION 1.1 This report presents the Brazil Health Sector Reform project for which a loan of US$300 million to the Federative Republic of Brazil is proposed. Total project cost is estimated at US$750 million. The loan would be a the Bank's standard variable interest rate, with a maturity of 15 years, including five years of grace. This report describes the health sector in Brazil, analyzes the issues it faces, and presents the Government's strategy to address these issues. The report then proposes the Bank's involvement in the financing of the Brazil health sector reform program, and provides parameters for project implementation. An analysis of the Brazilian economy is included in the Country Assistance Strategy for Brazil, discussed by the Board on June 6, 1995. The Government has presented its health sector reform program in a Letter of Health Policy (Annex J). 2. Organization and Financing of Health Care6 and 7 2.9 Brazil's Unified Health System (SUS), which is the sole source of publicly financed care for 110 million Brazilians, is unique in Latin America and more comparable to the model of Canada and several European countries. In the Constitution and in the SUS law: (a) it is a single-payer system; (b) coverage is universal; (c) health benefits are all-inclusive and free at the time of use; (d) financing comes mostly from general taxation and subsidizes the poor; (e) funds are allocated to states and municipalities on the basis of negotiated budgets, based on historical series; (f) most care is delivered by private providers who compete for patients; (g) providers are reimbursed on the basis of production (diagnosis-related groups); and (h) ownership and administration of public services is partially decentralized to municipalities and states. Private health insurance plays a significant complementary role for about 38 million people (26 percent of the population). A detailed description of the system is provided in Annex K. 2.10 Coverage. Despite the impressive degree to which the SUS coincides with good organizational and financial models, it has a number of significant shortcomings. Although coverage is in theory universal, the system leaves large areas and groups uncovered in the North and in periurban areas, where an estimated 10 million people do not have access to health care. With 30 hospital beds and 14.2 physicians per 10,000 population, Brazil compares favorably with the average for Latin America and other middle-income countries. The country has a relative scarcity of nurses, with a 3.7 doctor/nurse ratio and the distribution of health services and professionals in the various regions is very unequal, being concentrated in the most developed regions and in state capitals. In the Northeast, prenatal care coverage can be as low as 12 percent (e.g., the State of Piaui), and 31 percent of births still take place at home. 2.11 Benerits. Maternal care is often used in health services administration as a "tracer" for quality of care. If judged by maternal and infant mortality and morbidity, quality of care is likely to be very bad. Although 83 percent of births were officially attended by qualified staff in 1989, maternal mortality amd perinatal mortality are 45 percent higher than one would expect in a country with the income and education of Brazil, suggesting very poor obstetric practice. 2.17 Administration of Public Health Services. The Ministry of Health has few responsibilities in direct health care provision, as ownership and administration of public services have been decentralized to municipalities and states since 1988. Starting in 1982, successive administrations have decentralized both responsibilities and resources to municipalities and, to a lesser degree, to states. At present, about 2,000 of the 5,000 Brazilian municipalities have some degree of autonomy in health care. Decentralization has mostly benefited municipalities, leaving State Health Secretariats with a relatively small and ill-defined role, lying between a strong Federal MoH and the municipal health secretariats, over which they have no hierarchical authority, the latter tending to relate directly to the Federal level. Municipal Health Secretariats are responsible for planning, organizing, and managing public health care delivery in their jurisdiction, and can contract private providers to deliver the care not provided by the public network. When necessary, they can also form intermunicipal consortia9 to pool resources and better manage patient flows. Larger and better-managed municipalities with advanced administrative and financial autonomy receive block grants which they are free to manage. It is anticipated that some states will have full autonomy, meaning that in addition to receiving the block grants, they will be entrusted with the responsibility for general public health functions such as communicable disease control. 2.18 Provider Reimbursement. Health Care Expenditures 2.21 Public Health Expenditures were about US$19.1 billion in 1990, which represented US$95.6 per capita and 2.76 percent of the country's GDP. Such a level of expenditure is much smaller than the amount spent by other upper middle-income countries in the region. Total health expenditures in Argentina, Chile, Costa Rica, Mexico, Uruguay and Venezuela represent from 1.96 percent to 7.5 percent of GDP. In part because of the low public health expenditure, Brazil ranks last among the cited countries for life expectancy, infant mortality, maternal mortality, immunization, and prenatal care coverage.

Some of these failings can be addressed in the short-term within the current institutional arrangements, while others are structural and can only be fixed in the medium term. 3.2 Short-term Problems. The main short-term problem is that reimbursement of private providers is far out of line with the average cost of services, and the Government has often significant arrears. On average reimbursement schedules only cover 40 to 50 percent of costs and the Government often pays providers with delays of three to six months. Due to underfinancing, philanthropic hospitals, which are the backbone of the SUS, have been closing entire units, going out of business or canceling their public service contracts, while public hospitals are left decaying, without essential inputs and, leaving the poor without recourse to proper health care. During the past six years, lack of funds for investments has been endemic. As a result, many investment projects have remained unfinished and maintenance of capital has been neglected. These projects, if not completed, will deteriorate and their sunken costs will be lost. In addition, the present reimbursement schedule overcompensates some non-cost-effective tertiary interventions used by the rich, while it leaves more cost-effective essential public health and clinical interventions seriously undercompensated. 3.3 Structural Problems. There are five structural problems in the SUS. First and most important, the current constitutional mandate to pay for all health services for the entire population is not fiscally sustainable. Since 1987, capital investments in the health sector dropped by 37 percent. The quality and efficiency of health care delivery is low, and results largely from the deteriorated condition of facilities, including buildings and electromechanical equipment, medical equipment and support services. Hospitals are generally more deteriorated than health centers and posts. A large part of their basic

Many hospitals also suffer from deterioration of their physical plant, including plumbing, cooling, sanitary systems, and air conditioning. These bottlenecks in turn produce reductions in productivity (i.e., excessive lengths of stay and increased costs), and in the quality of care, and pose safety hazards to both staff and patients (i.e. radiation leaks, hospital infections, etc.). 3.6 The Federal Government has been until recently unable to adequately regulate the system, namely to ensure the quality of services it purchases, and to contro] fraud. Despite the major role of the private sector in both health care delivery and financing, regulation often does not exist or is poorly enforced. The quality of care is inadequate as it can be judged by the hospital fatality rate, which has been increasing since 1991 to reach the highest rate in ten years: 2.4 percent. In the area of fraud control, the record is equally poor: the Government estimates that fraud is present in over 10 percent of all hospital reimbursements, but other sources estimate that fraud may be present in as many as 40 percent of all reimbursements. Given the inadequate reimbursement rates and the need to keep health care providers in business, the Government has had difficulty in controlling fraud. 3.7 In addition and with few exceptions, public sector and many philanthropic hospitals are poorly managed, with: (a) inadequacy of inputs (i.e., human resources are heavily physician-biased); (b) above-average market prices for equipment expenditures; (c) widespread absenteeism reflected in low staff productivity; (d) low levels of hospital management autonomy, (e) accountability problems (managers are commonly appointed on the basis of political criteria); and (f) underdeveloped quality assurance programs. 3.8 Third, the system fails to cover the poor who have moved to new settlements in the North and to peri-urban areas. Driven by market forces, health care providers tend to concentrate their activities in the South and Southeast regions. Although this situation improved in 1980s when the number of hospital beds and ambulatory services grew at a faster rate in the North and Northeast than in the South and Southeast regions, the population of the latter regions still use nearly twice as many ambulatory services (4 consultation per person per year) as do their compatriots who live in poorer Northeast and North states (2-3 consultations per person per year). An estimated 10 million people, formally covered by the SUS, currently do not have real access to health care because they live in more remote areas. In addition, migration to large cities has created large peri- urban settlements (e.g. Baixada Fluminense, in the outskirts of Rio) where the social infrastructure is weak or nonexistent. The problem is worsened by the fact that recent fiscal tightness and low reimbursement rates have led to a reduction in the number of the publicly financed beds from 4.3 per thousand inhabitants in 1982 to 3.7 in 1992. 3.9 Fourth, reimbursement of providers constitutes only 40 percent of the MoH budget, a very low proportion, if one considers that the Ministry has few health care provision responsibilities. Federal agencies such as the National Health Foundation and
 14 the Central Pharmaceutical Agency, which could be for the most part decentralized, still consume 25 percent of the federal health budget resources. While the Constitution has passed down significant responsibilities to small and unprepared municipalities, it has not defined exactly the role of states, creating overlapping in the area of planning, and leaving serious doubts on how the system would be financed and controlled. 3.10 Finally, medical unit costs have been expanding exponentially, at twice the rate of the consumer price index, due to uncontrolled introduction of new technologies and pharmaceuticals, often of doubtful cost-effectiveness. Between 1980 and 1993, the annual health inflation index was on average 423%. From 1990 to 1994, the consumer price index and the health inflation index increased twice and three times more than the adjusted reimbursement rates, respectively. 3.11 All these failings can be corrected under the current institutional arrangements. The Government is planning a 10-year health sector reform program, of which the present project would be the first of a series of two or three consecutive projects, to repair the described shortcomings while improving the desirable features. The project will deal with a few of these problems, while others will be pursued through ongoing broad policy dialogue, technical assistance and possibly through other complementary loans and projects. Government Health Sector Policy 3.12 The proposed REFORSUS project is the main vehicle for the Government's health policy. The project would reinforce many of the positive features of the Brazilian Unified Health System and eliminate some of its present shortcomings. This is the first time that the Government of Brazil has requested Bank assistance for a policy-based sectoral operation. It is the product of several years of dialogue, health policy and economic and sector work (Annex L). As soon as the present Government took office in January 1995, the Minister of Health sought Bank assistance to respond to a health care crisis: reimbursement of health care providers was so out-of-line with the average cost of services that philanthropic hospitals, which are the backbone of the public health system, were closing entire units, going out of business or canceling their public service contracts and public hospitals, which essentially serve the poor, were left to decay, without essential inputs. 3.13 The ensuing dialogue led the Government to prepare the proposed project and to take emergency health policy initiatives. In its first year in office, the Government has (a) increased the provider reimbursement rates by 25 percent to keep philanthropic providers from leaving the public system and meet the operating costs of public providers; (b) created and operated a National Chamber of Health Care Price Negotiations to ensure adequate compensation of health care providers; (c) prepared, with Bank assistance, a limited list of most cost-effective interventions which will be fully reimbursed starting in 1996, to match the systems benefits with resource constraints; (d) introduced legislation
 15 which will allow cost recovery of care provided to privately- insured patients under the SUS; (e) proposed a budget for 1996 which will allow raising reimbursement rates to a level high enough to cover full costs of the most cost-effective interventions (described in the so called Priority I list -- para 4.9 and Annex N), protecting the system from further deterioration; (f) upgraded its management information system and instituted a National Audit System, which has resulted in a 10 percent reduction of fraudulent claim; (g) started using global health budgets (i.e. overall ceilings) for states and municipalities to improve control over expenditures; and (h) provided advanced administrative autonomy to 4 states and 83 municipalities, allowing them to receive block grants and to directly manage the financing of the sector. In addition, the Government has submitted legislation to Congress which will further increase decentralization to states and municipalities. These critical reform initiatives, discussed with the Government during project identification and preparation, have started to be implemented much faster that anticipated. 3.14 In the medium term, these measures need to be strengthened and complemented. The Government is planning a I 0-year health sector reform program, of which the present project would be the first of a series of two or three consecutive projects, to address the described shortcomings and improve, when feasible, the overall features of the system. At negotiations, the Government will present a Letter of Health Policy which describes reforms undertaken to date and a vision of where the Government would like the Unified Health System to be in 1998 (Annex J). The project would finance the necessary technical assistance and management information system to that effect. In addition, a parallel track of broad policy dialogue will be continued with the Government on important issues which would not be tackled by the project, for the sake of simplicity and implementability. 3.15 If the SUS reform program is implemented, by the year 2000: (a) coverage would continue to be universal, but; (b) the scope of health benefits financed under the SUS would be compatible with health sector revenues, and would favor more cost-effective interventions at the expense of less cost-effective interventions; (c) financing would continue to come mostly from taxation and subsidize the poor, but states and municipalities would take more responsibility, private insurers would be called to pay for services provided to their beneficiaries under the SUS; (d) the allocation of capital and recurrent health care budgets to states and municipalities would be mostly automatic and based on transparent and equity generating formulas, which would include income, health and supply indicators; (e) private providers would continue to be the backbone of public health care provision, but would be more accountable for the quality of services provided; (f) public hospitals and ambulatory services would be given administrative and financial autonomy; (g) reimbursements would be enough to maintain capital, and be used as incentives to promote cost-effective interventions and discourage use of public resources for less cost-effective ones; and (h) the Ministry of Health would keep the core of policy setting, regulation and financing, while shedding non-essential functions. If these policy reforms were implemented, the SUS would evolve toward more efficient, equitable and higher-quality medical care. To reach these objectives requires reform in three distinct areas: prices for services, management capacity, and investment.

PROJECT CONCEPT AND COMPOSITION Project Objectives 4.1 The project's main objectives are to: (a) improve the delivery of care under the SUS, which is the sole source of publicly subsidized care for the poor, and (b) assist the Government in introducing policy reforms which would improve the financial sustainability and efficiency of the SUS. 4.2 To improve the delivery of care, the project would set an investment fund to support rehabilitation, equipment, and management systems for SUS hospitals and ambulatory network. The project would improve the technical and management infrastructure in I 1 percent of the network. 4.3 To improve the financial sustainability and efficiency of the SUS, the project would strengthen the capacity of the MoH, the states, and municipalities in their role of health care purchasers, and assist the Government in preparing and implementing the necessary health sector finance reforms to: (a) ensure adequate compensation for health care providers, by establishing reimbursements rates which would be enough to maintain and replace capital; (b) protect the system from further deterioration of assets, by deciding on priority investments and necessary reimbursement levels on the basis of annual reviews of budget resources available for the SUS; (c) reduce revenue constraints by establishing cost recovery, and selecting a number of more cost-effective interventions to be financed under the SUS; (d) reduce fraud, by establishing systematic audit and improving the reimbursement management information system; and (e) control federal expenditures by adopting global health budget transfers to states and municipalities.

SOCIO-ECONOMIC AND FINANCIAL ANALYSIS Linkage with Economic and Sector Work (ESW) and Country Assistance Strategy (CAS) 7.1 The project is consistent with the most recent health sector work in the World Bank generally (1993 World Development Report), and in Brazil (The Organization, Delivery, and Financing of Health Care in Brazil, Rep. 12655-BR, and Private Sector and Social Services in Brazil: Who Pays, Who Delivers, Who Finances, Rep. 13205-BR), particularly with respect to the problems of underfinancing, inequity, inadequate regulation, fraud and poor quality of medical care. Most recommendations of that sector work would be implemented through the project. 7.2 The project fully supports the Bank's strategy for the health sector in Brazil as described in the Country Assistance Strategy (CAS) for Brazil and discussed by the Board of Directors on June 29, 1995, as well as the Country Assistance Strategy update to be discussed at the Board in June 1996. In health, the Bank's goal is to help the Government (a) improve the management, financial viability, and quality of public health care systems which serve the poor; (b) carry out its role as a provider of public goods; and (c) encourage investments for the underserved and vulnerable groups. In the CAS, a health reform loan is considered of sufficient priority to be included in the Bank's portfolio, even under the low case of high inflation and low overall lending. 7.3 The strategy makes two strong recommendations: "to develop and implement a formula for transferring federal funds to the states and municipalities that improves equity" and "to develop a package of essential services of acceptable quality compatible with the present level of public health expenditure". The project would incorporate the first of those recommendations by means of a formula for pre-assigning investment funds among states, based on poverty and health indicators as well as population, before approving
 31 subproject proposals within each state. Besides improving equity, this formula will prevent a large share of investments from going to those states with greater capacity to formulate subprojects. The second recommendation in the CAS, to publicly find only a limited list of interventions at current spending levels, has been rejected by the Government, on the basis that it would contradict the Constitutional requirement of free health care. However, as indicated above, the Government has agreed to distinguish among interventions and pay the full cost of those on a priority list of more cost-effective services, while paying less than full cost for lower-priority interventions. It has also committed to increasing federal health spending to cover the agreed differentiated rise in reimbursement rates. 7.4 The project would be complemented by a parallel track of broad political dialogue which would address a number of important sector issues not addressed by the project, for the sake of project simplicity and implementability: (a) role and size of the National Health Foundation -- FUNASA and Central Pharmaceutical Agency -- CEME, (b) management of the introduction and diffusion of advanced technologies in the SUS, and (c) size of the MoH payroll. The Bank has reviewed the terms of reference for the relevant technical assistance, which would be financed under the project. In addition, the Bank is considering a Government concept paper for a possible project which would decentralize the control of infectious disease to states and municipalities, addressing the role and size of FUNASA in a decentralized SUS. It is also initiating sector work that could lead to a follow-up operation in the Northeast. 7.5 The project is also consistent with the recommendations of the HDD paper for the Board, "Getting Results in the Social Sectors: An Agenda for Action." In particular, that paper recommends focusing less on a "blueprint" and more on a process. The project does exactly that: it does not specify the content of the investments to be financed, but does specify the process for selecting, financing and evaluating them. Similarly, it specifies a process for setting tariffs to providers according to the costs and the priority of interventions. Analysis of Project Alternatives 7.6 The project would primarily finance investments in infrastructure and management of publicly-owned or publicly financed non-profit private health care facilities. This raises questions at three levels: first, what would happen if there were no project, or if the Bank did not participate in it? Second, should it be a single project, or would it be advisable to delay an investment operation until reforms were better defined and implemented? Third, what is the best project design? In particular, (a) should the investment be limited to publicly-owned facilities? (b) should private non-profit providers be fully subsidized or have to repay part of the investment under the project? and (c) should private for-profit providers also have access to the investment funds? 7.7 The diagnosis of the current situation of SUS is that it cannot continue to function with payments to providers that are on average well below costs. If tariffs are not raised,
 32 two trends will accelerate: those able to afford private insurance or obtain it through their employment will abandon the publicly-financed system, and the quality and coverage of care available to those who depend on the public system will deteriorate further. In the absence of an investment and reform project, therefore, there would still be a need to raise tariffs, and in fact the Govemment already did raise them by 25 percent, and is committed to another 15 percent increase in 1996, differentiated by the cost-effectiveness of interventions. 7.8 If the situation of the SUS were in other respects the same as it is now, but the Government had not undertaken any of the reforms described earlier, there would be a strong argument for holding off an investment operation. At the moment, some proposed reforms are at the conceptual stage and have not been tested; this is the case for the use of differentiated tariffs to induce changes in output toward greater cost-effectiveness, and for recovery of costs from privately-insured patients. However, the Government has already made substantial progress in negotiating expenditure ceilings, abolishing quantitative controls on ambulatory care procedures and allowing states and municipalities to shift resources between hospital and ambulatory care, improving the detection of fraud, and raising tariffs overall. To hold off longer on needed investments, especially those where large costs have already been sunk without result, or those where small sums for rehabilitation would markedly improve the quantity or quality of services, would actually jeopardize gains already made by the ongoing reform. 7.9 The third question, of the right design for a single investment operation which will support existing and planned reforms, can be broken down into three more specific issues. Limiting the investment to publicly-owned facilities would ignore the fact that SUS operates to a large extent through non-profit private hospitals and clinics that depend overwhelmingly on public financing. To discriminate against them would make it hard for them to continue functioning in competition with the publicly-owned services, and would reduce the technical efficiency of the system even further. It would also affect equity, since the distribution of capacity between public and private non-profit facilities varies from place to place and from service to service; limiting the investment to public facilities would favor some areas and interventions, but not necessarily those that the project should promote. Therefore it was decided that, on the grounds of both equity and efficiency, no distinction should be made between publicly-owned facilities and those that are publicly- financed but private non-profit. This does not mean that the nature of investments will be the same in the two sub-sectors, because the public sector includes many more projects that were left unfinished during the fiscal crisis of 1992-93, whereas the philanthropic sector needs a larger number of smaller rehabilitation investments for facilities that are already functioning. To ensure that the larger, incomplete public sub-projects do not use up all the investment resources, the Govemment has agreed to pre-assign 25 percent of the funds to private non-profit facilities. 7.10 Project financing of investment in such a facility should be limited to the share that will be used to provide services to the SUS, because some philanthropic facilities depend on SUS for only part of their revenue and eam the rest by selling services to privately- insured patients. Two subsidiary issues remain unresolved: (i) even a partial subsidy may
 33 lead to investments on services sold in a greater proportion to non-SUS buyers; investment proposals from providers that receive substantial revenues from non- SUS sources may therefore get closer screening or auditing than others; and (ii) SUS/non-SUS revenue shares may not be stable over time; thus, the choice of which year(s) to use in calculating the project share in investment will be somewhat arbitrary. Neither difficulty prevents the project from funding all non-profit facilities under the same criteria in proportion to their dependence on SUS. 7.11 Private for-profit providers will not receive financing from the proceeds of the loan. They will, however, have access to loans provided by the BNDES. BNDES will apply to its loans to private for-profit health care providers, the same criteria that the project would apply to public and non-profit investment proposals. This might reduce the BNDES health facility loans in return for pushing private borrowers toward the criteria of equity and allocative efficiency that the project is meant to promote. 7.12 Two types of onlending terms were considered: (a) subloans on terms equivalent to the Bank loan, or (b) grants linked to establishment of performance contracts and clear output indicators. The first option was rejected because of (a) the immediate fiscal impact of raising tariffs in the short run to a level which would cover the costs of capital, (b) more complicated implementation arrangements, and (c) lessons learned in other countries (eg. Philippines), in which it has been difficult to recover loans to public and philanthropic hospitals. Fiscal Impact and Project Sustainability 7.13 Project sustainability depends on the capacity of the Government to cover the operating costs of the SUS. Such costs can be expected to increase as a result of: (a) increased tariffs paid by the SUS (this will be largest fiscal impact); (b) increased recurrent expenditures to make use of the capital created or restored by the project; (c) higher volume of some services due to the investments or stimulated by the tariff increases; and (d) population growth. There are two potential sources of reduced costs: reduction in fraud (which would allow buying the same real services at lower expenditure or more services for the same money), and recovery of costs from privately insured patients (provided new legislation allows this). The project will also reallocate resources from low priority areas to higher priority areas. 7.14 Tariff Changes. Estimates of SUS spending for 1996 already include an average increase of 34 percent in tariffs, with respect to their 1995 level. This will rise to 50 percent in 1997, after which tariffs are assumed constant in real terms: it is estimated that tariffs need to rise between 50 and 70 percent to cover the costs of most services. With differentiated tariffs, and assuming that average prices are the same for both more- and less cost-effective services, a 50 percentage average tariff increase is compatible with raising SUS prices by 70 percent on 70 percent of output, and no increase in services. Alternatively, there could be a 70 percent rise on half of current output and an increase of 18 percent in the services whose relative price increased. If nothing else happened except this adjustment to average tariffs, and an increase of two percent per year to accommodate
 34 population growth, SUS expenditure would rise to almost US$12.7 billion by the year 2001. 7.15 How changes in tariffs will affect output of services and expenditure on them is unknown, because SUS operates under three kinds of federal controls at once: on the tariffs paid to producers for services, on the number of patients whose hospitalizations (9 per 100 population per year) will be financed, and on total expenditure by the federal government, state by state. Institutional Capacity Analysis and Lessons Learned from Previous Bank Operations in Brazil 7.30 The REFORSUS project would complement five other projects in Brazil. Presently, Brazil has one of the Bank's largest portfolios, being, as of June 1995, the fifth largest in terms of number of commitments and the fourth largest in number of ongoing projects. Since 1949, the Bank has financed 122 projects in Brazil. From these projects, including the ones in health, the Bank has drawn several relevant lessons. In particular, the Bank has faced the following problems in implementing projects in Brazil (i) frequent changes in Government policy; (ii) inadequate project design; (iii) poor management arrangements; and (iv) excessive number of covenants. 7.31 Changes in Government Policy. In the past, various changes in Ministry positions have often resulted in decreasing commitment by the Brazilian authorities to project objectives. During the last 15 years, projects have had their implementation timeframe altered and new government administrators have decided not to continue the previous administration's projects. Yet these problems seem to have been partially reduced lately with the successful implementation of an economic reform that has diminished both the political and financial instability in the country. After experiencing inflation rates up to 2000 percent a year, for the first time Brazil is being able to keep it in acceptable levels and to grow economically. Other factors positively influencing the project are: (i) the large amount of human and physical resources that has been invested in the project during its preparation; (ii) the number of stakeholders extensively involved in project identification, preparation and appraisal (para. 7.38 -- 7.40); in case of governmental change, one could expect sufficient consensus on the objectives and design of the project to maintain it among the priorities of other governments; and (iii) finally, the municipalities, states and non-profit health care providers, who would prepare and present subprojects and ultimately be the major beneficiaries of the project and make up a strong constituency for the overall project. 7.32 Inadequate Project Design. Several projects in Brazil have been preceded by poor institutional analysis. The lack of institutional studies and blueprint designs have been reflected in the layout and implementation of projects, which most often had to be reviewed during execution, causing delays in implementation and additional costs. The REFORSUS project, besides being preceded by broad institutional discussions and support, has been designed as a demand-driven fund-like project, whereby funds are allocated to different geographical areas on the basis of agreed criteria, and subprojects
 40 are presented by the beneficiaries, ensuring them ownership. This demand-driven approach will facilitate the implementation of the project. 7.33 Poor Project Implementation Arrangements. The structure of the Brazilian public sector, the number of covenants and transactions involved in each project, and the lack of adequate assistance on the part of federal government to ongoing projects, all of them have constituted a source of frustration for the Bank. For the REFORSUS project, three problems have been identified during appraisal: (a) the MoH procedures are cumbersome and its administrative capacity is often low; (b) a large number of financial transactions between the Bank and the ultimate contractor or beneficiary has delayed disbursement and implementation; and (c) Federal project management units have not been able to provide adequate technical assistance and supervision to a large number of states. Although the MoH is burdened by cumbersome administrative procedures, it has been able to successfully manage five Bank-financed projects, and the latest operation - AIDS and STD Control (Ln.3659-BR), has been well-managed. The project would use BNDES and BB as financial agents, which would contract directly with the beneficiary or with the providers of works, goods or technical assistance. Such an arrangement would avoid the ministry's bureaucracy and reduce the number of financial transactions between the Bank and the contractor or beneficiary. The MoH would keep the technical appraisal and supervision functions, areas in which it is strong, while it would subcontract to BNDES and BB all administrative and financial transactions. The PCU regional technical assistance offices would help weaker states and municipalities in subproject preparation, evaluation and supervision. In addition, the MoH would retain the services of an independent consulting firm for purposes of carrying out evaluations of subprojects. 7.34 Excessive Number of Covenants. Conditionality was reduced to the greatest extent possible and set, as much as possible to be fulfilled at negotiations. The remaining covenants, considered as critical to the sustainability of the project would be monitored in November 1997 and 1998 (Annex J). 7.35 Performance Indicators. ENVIRONMENTAL ANALYSIS 8.1 The REFORSUS project has given a B environmental rating. The project would have a positive environmental impact by specifically addressing the issue of safe handling of medical waste. An environmental study for the health sector in Brazil was carried out as part of preparation, to review the main sector issues and to set the environmental requirements for subprojects to be financed under the project: beneficiaries would have to present adequate environmental and safety management plans addressing such issues as the segregation and handling of wastes, their further transportation and disposal away from the health facility, and training of facility employees on environmental and safety issues. BENEFITS AND RISKS 9.1 Benefits. The project is a targeted poverty alleviation intervention and would benefit mostly the poor who have the SUS as their only source of publicly subsidized health care. The revision of the reimbursement rates will correct price distortions which specifically disadavantaged the poor, while the proposed investments and resource allocation formula would redirect public investment toward physical infrastructure and basic health services for the poor. Given that this is a demand-driven project it is difficult to estimate ex-ante the overall economic benefits which will depend on the volume and composition of individual subprojects. However basic assumptions using comparable
 44 regional experiences"2 show that improved the access and the quality of basic clinical and public health services when provided in a poor area could avoid about 10 percent of the burden of disease, measured in reduced number of disease-adjusted life-years lost. Family medicine pioneer experiments in Brazil have been successful: in Parana, between 1986 and 1994, the program reduced infant malnutrition from 18 percent to 4 percent, increased vaccination rates from 47 to 75 percent, broadened coverage of prenatal care by 33 percent, and reduced hospital admissions by 20 percent. Relative priority will be given to maternal and infant care services, to emergency and trauma centers. Studies in Mexico suggest that delivery and perinatal care could reduce 47 adjusted life years lost due to maternal causes per 100 beneficiaries, per year. Expert opinion suggests that adequate emergency and trauma services could reduce, in the respective catchment areas, the number of life-years lost due to accidents and other external causes by 20 percent, and save 6 disability-adjusted life-years per beneficiary per year. 9.2 Equity. Although the project is not designed specifically to address the issue of equity, it will increase the proportion of investments in poor states by establishing new formulas for allocating health budgets to states on the basis of population, income and health indicators and installed capacity, thus reducing the discrepancy between rich states in the South and Southeast and poor ones in the Northeast. In addition, the project would limit the reimbursement of expensive tertiary interventions with little cost-effectiveness, which are used free of charge by privately insured middle- and upper-class patients. 9.3 Efficiency. The project will improve the allocative efficiency of the SUS by increasing the proportion of public health funds spent on cost-effective interventions. Priority will be given to subprojects in the areas of maternal, child, family health and emergency and trauma care, where more cost-effective interventions are delivered, and to clear public goods such as blood banks and public health laboratories. In addition, the project will establish a new framework for pricing and reimbursing health care providers which will favor the reimbursement of more cost-effective interventions at the expense of less cost-effective ones. 9.4 Finally, the project would improve the internal efficiency of the SUS by: (a) restoring the system's capacity, (b) putting idle complementary resources back into use; (c) reducing the cost of interventions already being provided; (d) improving the reimbursement system; (d) requiring improved management systems as a condition for receiving funding for rehabilitation and equipment; and (e) reducing fraud. By restoring the system's capacity, the project would increase the number of patients treated, and allow a more efficient utilization of diagnostic equipment, beds, and operating suites. Health care management improvement may improve hospital efficiency (i.e. higher occupancy rates, shorter lengths of stay, higher bed turnover, higher number of patients treated). It is expected that services will better reflect the needs of beneficiaries and that accountability and social control will improve. The return of inflation would make the proposed price adjustments extremely difficult. The effect of inflation could only be mitigated through indexation of prices to inflation, but this would only contribute to the inflationary spiral. The change of government policy would bring a delay in project implementation but is unlikely to bring the project to a halt, given the significant stakeholder support ensured during project identification and preparation (para. 7.31). The risk of project breakdown would be minimized by continuing to involve the stakeholders in the identification, preparation and execution of subprojects, and by selecting investments on the basis of clear and transparent criteria which could be supported by any government.  60 Annex G BRAZIL Health Sector Reform Project -- REFORSUS G. TERMS OF REFERENCE OF KEY STUDIES 1. Burden of Disease Study Background 1. Health planning has been based on traditional health indicators such as mortality and morbidity rates, incidence and prevalence of disease and health services supply indicators-number of beds, and number of physicians per 10,000 people. None of the indicators used until recently has been able to establish an indication of combined lifetime effects of premature mortality and permanent or temporary disability due to illness. Studying the national burden of disease in Brazil will obtain such an indicator: DALYs (Disability-Adjusted Life Years); the estimation obtains the number of DALYs lost to premature mortality and those lost due to disability given the present epidemiological profile of the country. The study will also provide information on the number of DALYs associated to health risk factors such as smoking, or alcohol abuse. DALYs will be calculated at the National and State level, by sex and age groups. 2. The Government of Brazil is introducing policy reforms which would improve the financial viability, efficiency and management of the Unified Health System -- SUS, and would expand and improve the delivery of the SUS which is the sole source of care for the poor. The World Bank and IDB are supporting the Government with a loan to finance the referenced project, which includes two major components: I -- Improvement of health care delivery in the SUS, which will fund rehabilitation and equipment, management improvement and family health and health promotion subprojects; and II -- Improvement of health care financing and regulation, which will establish a sustainable mechanism to finance the system, control fraud and ensure the quality of care and promote the decentralization of responsibilities and resources to states and municipalities. 3. The project will support decentralization of health care financing and administration from federal level to states and municipalities, to improve responsiveness to local needs, to improve accountability and avoid overheads associated with the present centralized system. The decentralization process must be accompanied by well informed health planning processes of states and municipalities; the Burden of Disease study will improve national and local capability for establishing health priorities.
 61 Annex G Objectives 4. The main objective of the study is: (a) to calculate the total burden of disease at the national and state level in 1995 associated to communicable or transmissible diseases (Group I), non-transmissible diseases (Group II) and violence (Group III). (b) analyze Burden of Disease results and highlight health priorities to guide health policy regarding: (i) resource allocation; (ii) design of health programs. Scope of work 5. To carry out the study, the researchers would: (a) collect all mortality, morbidity and demographic data available. (b) correct mortality data by volume (to correct underreporting) and by quality (disease classification imperfections) and create data base. (c) generate life tables for Brazil. (d) create data bases on disease incidence by age, sex and region. (e) develop by national expert consultation, and/or structured surveys, information to estimate disability weights for each disease, illness age of onset, duration of illness, etc. (f) calculate DALYs due to early mortality, and to morbidity at the national and state levels, by age and sex. (g) calculate DALYs by risk factors. (h) analyze results and discuss with health policy makers. (i) analyze burden of disease which could be averted by improving and targeting resource allocation. General Requirement 6. The preliminary report should be presented and discussed with the participation of health authorities at different government levels, research institutions, public and private health providers. 7. The expertise of demographers, epidemiologists, statistician/data base managers, and health economists, is needed for the development of the study.

 63 Annex G BRAZIL Health Sector Reform Project -- REFORSUS G. Terms of Reference of Key Studies 2. Cost-Effectiveness Study Background I. Introducing new tools to establish health priorities is an important task for health planners and policy makers. To allocate limited health resources where higher health gains can be achieved at lower cost is important for the sector's efficiency. The possibility of introducing a measure of the number of DALYs (health gains) obtained by the allocation of each dollar in the prevention and treatment of specific diseases is achieved by the analysis of the cost-effectiveness of a group of interventions. Studying the cost- effectiveness of a group of interventions in Brazil will allow to establish priorities among them, in order to guide resource allocation towards those where health gains achieved are higher for each dollar invested. 2. The Government of Brazil is introducing policy reforms which would improve the financial viability, efficiency and management of the Unified Health System -- SUS, and would expand and improve the delivery of the SUS which is the sole source of care for the poor. The World Bank and the IDB are supporting the Government with a loan to finance the referenced project, which includes two major components: I -- Improvement of health care delivery in the SUS, which will fund rehabilitation and equipment, management improvement and family health and health promotion subprojects; and II -- Improvement of health care financing and regulation, which will establish a sustainable mechanism to finance the system, control fraud and ensure the quality of care and promote the decentralization of responsibilities and resources to states and municipalities. 3. The project will support the introduction of mechanisms to improve resource allocation where health gains obtained are higher. This is also important for SUS resource allocation in the context of decentralization in order to improve responsiveness to local health needs, accountability and resource allocation. The decentralization process must be accompanied by well-informed health planning processes of states and municipalities; the Burden of Disease study and the study of cost-effectiveness of interventions will improve national and local capability for establishing health priorities. Objectives 4. The main objective of the study is: (a) to estimate the cost-effectiveness of health interventions in Brazil; and
 64 (b) to prioritize health interventions according to their cost-effectiveness and in conjunction with other criteria used by policy makers and health planners when applying the concept to resource allocation. Scope of work 5. To carry out the study the researchers would: (a) define health interventions associated to the treatment and prevention of each of the diseases being considered, which implies the preparation of a treatment "protocol". (b) to estimate the cost of those interventions based on the provision of services in Brazil, as a result of considering different types of providers. Then costs estimates will be representative of different levels of efficiency, salary levels, and the cost level of other health inputs. (c) estimate the effectiveness of interventions according to Brazilian characteristics, including: demographics, economic conditions, supply of health services, access to health care, utilization patterns,and incidence of diseases. (d) construct data bases for the interventions to be considered with their estimated cost, the associated Burden of Disease, the efficacy of those interventions (from world wide clinical trials in the literature) and disease incidence. (e) estimate cost-effectiveness ratios for the interventions considered and rank them accordingly. (f) analyze and discuss results with health planners, health researchers and international experts. General Requirement 6. The preliminary report should be presented and discussed with the participation of health authorities at different levels of government, research institutions, public and private health providers and international experts who will contribute with experiences in other countries. 7. Health economists, data management and information systems experts, physicians and an epidemiologist are needed for the implementation of the study. Over the past ten years, the reorganization of Brazil's health system has brought about significant changes in the legal, managerial, and institutional aspects of the system, especially by unifying and decentralizing activities. The 1988 Federal Constitution, with its repercussions on the State Constitutions (1989) and the Municipal Organic Laws (1990), and Federal Laws Nos. 8080/90 and 8142/90, provides a legal framework that is conducive to and provides an incentive for basic changes in the health system. It provided for the management of the health network to be decentralized gradually, in stages. Management conditions were introduced for states and municipalities, under which they would increasingly take over management of resources transferred by the federal government. In addition, forums for interinstitutional negotiations were set up, including the Tripartite Intermanagement Committee at federal level and the Bipartite Intermanagement Committee at state level, made up of representatives of the Ministry of Health, states, and municipalities and formed for the purpose of negotiating, drawing up proposals, and monitoring the introduction and operation of the SUS, under the supervision of the National and State Health Councils. This process of organizational reform has not been accompanied by increased financing for the sector. On the contrary, flows of financial resources into the sector have continued to be limited and have even been further reduced. In view of the volatility of this financing and the lack of an adequate remuneration policy for service providers, investment has declined and the quality of services rendered has dropped sharply. Both public health care units and supplementary private
 77 ones have become noticeably obsolete, and inequalities and deficiencies in health care coverage and hygiene have worsened. Fees of health care providers have lagged so far behind the average cost of services that philanthropic hospitals, the backbone of the public health system, have shut down units or dropped out of the system, while public hospitals have reduced the number of beds and the range of services offered. This deterioration has forced the present government to look for ways to remedy the situation. One way is to further the decentralization process initiated in 1993, by strengthening the Bipartite and Tripartite Committees, by allowing states and municipalities greater autonomy in management, and by guaranteeing a larger volume of federal resources to be transferred as part of the general budget. This process is being consolidated through the new SUS Basic Operating Rule, meant to further the decentralization process by including automatic, direct transfers of financial resources to states and by giving greater responsibility for operating the SUS to State and Municipal Health Secretariats. The Rule is also intended to revise the basis of the system for paying for services provided by focusing on per capita remuneration for primary health care and to define a list of incentives to accelerate the reform process. In addition to these changes in the Basic Operating Rule, the Ministry of Health has also endeavored to do the following: ensure adequate compensation to health care providers; protect the system from subsequent deterioration by making the necessary changes; reduce fraud and increase the quality of services, provide for a more equitable allocation of resources to cover current and capital costs; and, control and stabilize expenditures. In its effort to guarantee that health care providers receive adequate compensation for their services, in 1995 the Ministry granted a 25% cost of living adjustment in hospital and outpatient procedures, and established a price negotiation board made up of managers and representatives of service providers. In addition, we plan to publish new fee schedules including differential adjustments based on which procedures are most cost-effective and full payment for diagnostic or treatment procedures. It was our concern to reduce fraud and guarantee the quality of services that led to the introduction of Decree No. 1651/95, which was signed by the President of the Republic and regulates the National Audit System (SNA), and to the creation of the National Quality Health Care Committee. In the area of primary health care, a per capita remuneration arrangement is being worked out to guarantee that all citizens will be treated equally. As for the allocation of resources for investment, a formula was devised to compensate those states and municipalities with fewer health care services and thus with reduced public expenditures, so as to increase coverage of the population.  92 Annex 0 BRAZIL Health Sector Reform Project -- REFORSUS 0. ALLOCATION OF REFORSUS INVESTMENT CEILINGS BY STATE 1. REFORSUS will finance investments under a decentralized, competitive arrangement in which states, municipalities and philanthropic providers submit proposals for sub-projects. This procedure runs the risk that some states, with a greater capacity to generate proposals, would end up getting too large a share of the funds, leaving too little for states which were slower to submit proposals. To avoid this, the total fund available for investment will be pre-allocated among the states, establishing an initial ceiling for each state. A state will not automatically receive that much money; instead the ceiling will reserve those funds to be invested if there are enough acceptable sub-project proposals to absorb them. If the ceiling for a particular state is not reached during the life of the project, despite technical assistance from the Ministry in preparing sub-projects, the unused funds can be reallocated to other states which still have acceptable proposals pending. 2. A formula for the state-by-state pre-allocation of funds has been agreed. This formula: (a) Allocates not less than half the total investment fund in proportion to population, in order to be consistent with the rule that at least 50 percent of recurrent SUS expenditures be allocated by population; (b) Takes into account, in order to allocate the rest of the funds not strictly proportional to population, one or more variables associated with greater needs for investment, such as health status, poverty, or the current pattern of SUS expenditure; and (c) Is transpare'nt and easy to explain and justify to state and municipal officials, directors of health facilities, and the public. 3. The first two of these requirements are satisfied by the general class of formulas Fe/F = a(Pe/P) + (1-a)(Xe/X), where e refers to a particular state (estado) F is the investment fund to be pre-allocated P is population
 93 a is a parameter to be chosen, subject to the restriction that it be less than 1.0 and greater than or equal to 0.5 (1 > a > 0.5), and X is an indicator of need for additional investment (beyond that associated with population alone), which may be a single variable or a function of several variables.. 4. In order for the formula never to take away from a state, part of the ceiling distributed according to population, Xe must be non-negative. A zero value implies that the state gets no more funds than it is entitled to on the basis of population alone--that is, it is already a favored state. In addition, in order for the formula to allocate all of F exactly, without further adjustment, it is necessary for X to be the sum of the Xe across all the states, just as P is the sum of the state populations, Pe. With this condition, summing the formula across states yields F = aP + (1-a)X, so that a is exactly the share of the total fund allocated according to population, and (1-a) is the share allocated according to X. The restriction that the Xe add up to total X means that X cannot he a ratio or other non-linear function of whatever variables are used to compose it. (Ratios can nonetheless be used in the constructiotn of X.) 5. To satisfy the third requirement, that the formula be comprehensible and politically acceptable, imposes other, less exact, restrictions on the indicator X. It must be based on variables that can be measured without ambiguity, and it should not involve any complicated calculations. 6. The Ministry thinks that X should be based on SUS recurrent expenditures (G for gasto ), because: (a) It is under the Ministry's control (b) Expenditure should already bear some relation to other variables which might be used to construct X, such as the prevalence of poverty in the state or the size and nature of the burden of disease, (c) Data on expenditure by state are unambiguous and publicly available; and (d) Since state officials are always likely to claim that their state does not get enough funds, what is needed is simply a measure of what is "enough". 7. Discussion among the Ministry, the Inter-American Development Bank and the World Bank ended with agreement on the following construction of the indicator X: 8. First, per capita expenditure Ge/Pe is calculated in each state. The highest value is denoted (G/P)m. (m indicates the state where the ratio is maximal--it does not necessarily mean the state with the highest expenditure or the highest population. m
 94 happens at present to refer to Parana; per capita expenditure is only slightly lower in Sao Paulo.) 9. Next, the ratio (G/P)m is multiplied by Pe, the population of state e: this creates the variable Gem =(GJP)m(Pe) which is what expenditure in state e would be if per capita spending there were as high as in the state with the most expenditure per person--for example, how much SUS would spend in Para if the expenditure per head in that state were the same as in Parana. The sum of the Gem over all the states is denoted Gm: it is the amount that would be spent in all of Brazil if the per capita expenditure were everywhere as high as in Parana. Then actual expenditure Ge is subtracted from this estimate of maximal expenditure to yield Xe = Gem - Ge which means that Xe can be interpreted as a kind of "gap" or shortfall of expenditure in state e compared to state m. Clearly, Xm = 0 (State m, being the most favored already, has no shortfall to make up and therefore is not entitled to any more investment funds than are distributed according to population alone); Xe> 0 for every other state e (So no state has any money taken away, that was already assigned according to population); and The sum of the Xe is equal to X, which is the total shortfall in the whole country, or the amount of additional expenditure that would be needed in order to raise per capita spending everywhere to the level in the state (Parana) where it is highest now. 10. The final formula is then Fe/F = a(Pe/P) + (1-a)(Gem - Ge)/(Gm - G) I. Several possible complications to this formula were received. For example, the need for medical care is not simply proportional to population but depends on the age distribution, so it is arguable that Pe should somehow be adjusted for age composition. However, this would make the formula for investment allocation differ from the pure population basis on which part of recurrent spending is assigned. And since there is no one way to "adjust" for age distribution, this would cause more argument over the formula and make it harder to accept politically. Similarly, Ge might be complicated by including state or municipal as well as federal expenditures, or in other ways. But that would take the variable out of the control of the Ministry, would make it less transparent, and might
 95 even create a perverse incentive for a state to spend less of its own resources in order to claim a larger share of the REFORSUS investment funds. None of the possible subtleties or complications to the formula appeared to improve it sufficiently in technical terms, to justify the consequent ambiguities and political difficulties. 12. The parameter a is necessarily arbitrary, since the only requirement is that it lie between 0.5 and 1.0 The Banks and the Ministry agreed that it should fall somewhere in the middle of that range, so that Xe, the expenditure-related indicator, can actually have some impact on the allocation of funds, but not so much as to make the allocation depart greatly from proportionality to population. A value of a = 0.7 appears satisfactory: 70 percent of the ceiling allocated according to population and 30 percent according to expenditure shortfall. 13. doc.abstracts: The main objectives of the Health Sector Reform Project (REFORSUS) are to: 1) improve the delivery of care under the Sistema Unico de Saude/Unified Health System (SUS), which is the sole source of publicly subsidized care for the poor; and 2) assist the government in introducing policy reforms which would improve the financial sustainability and efficiency of the SUS. The project will finance the following two components: 1) an investment fund to finance rehabilitation, equipment, management and maintenance subprojects; and 2) institutional development, which will support: an adequate framework for pricing and reimbursing health care providers; a list of priority health benefits to be financed by the SUS; a differentiated reimbursement schedule favoring more cost-effective interventions; the introduction of cost recovery for care provided to privately-insured patients under the SUS; and better management of the quality of services and fraud control.
